sec_txt.h3: Extraordinary Cases of VTE Prevention in Patients With Cancer
CLOT: A Landmark Study for Treatment of Cancer-Associated Thrombosis[1]

ul.li: Despite the demonstrated value of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) in reducing the risk of recurrent venous thromboembolism (VTE) in patients with cancer, many patients are reluctant to inject themselves daily, which presents an opportunity for the use of non-vitamin K antagonist oral anticoagulants (NOACs) and a greater chance for adherence to anticoagulant treatment

sec_txt.h3: Risk of Recurrent VTE in Cancer[4]
Clinical Implications of Hokusai VTE-Cancer and SELECT-D[2,5]

ul.li:
Dr Kakkar: In a patient with pancreatic malignancy
If the tumor is in the head of pancreases eroding into the duodenum, it is likely affecting the mucosa and associated with a potentially higher risk for bleeding
If the tumor is firmly confined in the head of pancreas, with no duodenal infringement, it is likely not associated with a higher risk for gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding

sec_txt.h3: Use of NOACs in Cancer-Associated VTE: Considerations for GI Tract

ul.li: Dr Crowther: One of the experiences I have had in this area, is that some patients have a very strong preference for not self-injecting, and other patients think that self-injection implies that the treatment is more powerful -- it is important when talking with patients to have a discussion about which is the optimal therapy
